intro: Schismus aristulatus, commonly known as the narrowleaf sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial herb with linear, grass-like leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in summer, typically in clusters at the ends of the stems. Schismus aristulatus is adapted to survive in dry, sandy soils and can thrive in full sun. Its fibrous roots help stabilize soil, making it a valuable plant in desert ecosystems.
